SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 5 topic or subject area.
Content: What does the word “terrain” mean as it is used in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: bodies of water

B.Choice: plant life

C.Choice: surface features of the land

D.Choice: area with small amounts of rain

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which detail best reflects the main goal of the Haughton Mars Project?

A.Choice: “Now I have some idea of what it's like to be on the Red Planet.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “That means people can work there only during the summer months ...” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “Others test how well their robot rovers collect rock and soil samples.” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “Recent robot missions there found possible signs of frozen water.” (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence best supports the main idea of paragraphs 3 through 5?

A.Choice: “It is about 900 miles from the North Pole.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “It lets them figure out what they would need to make human explorations of Mars successful and safe.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “Scientists have been studying Mars for decades.” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “NASA officials have said that they hope to put astronauts on the Red Planet by 2030.” (paragraph 11)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Which evidence best supports the point the author makes in paragraph 11?

A.Choice: Scientists are practicing tasks they might perform on Mars.

B.Choice: Scientists work on the island during the summer months.

C.Choice: Scientists have gathered on the island since 1997.

D.Choice: Scientists are limiting phone and Internet use.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: The main reason no one lives on Devon Island is because the island

A.Choice: is difficult to reach

B.Choice: has no Internet service

C.Choice: is cold most of the year

D.Choice: has continuous sunlight all summer

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: How have recent robot missions to Mars affected future exploration by humans?

A.Choice: The missions determined when humans can safely travel to Mars.

B.Choice: The missions suggested that humans will be able to survive on Mars.

C.Choice: The missions discovered proof of life on Mars that only humans can confirm.

D.Choice: The missions raised new questions about life on Mars that humans may answer.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Why does the author quote Dr. Pascal Lee throughout the article?

A.Choice: Dr. Lee is the scientist on the island who has the most information about Mars.

B.Choice: Dr. Lee was hired by NASA to be the next scientist to explore Mars.

C.Choice: Dr. Lee started the Haughton Mars Project and has remained involved since its beginning.

D.Choice: Dr. Lee lives at the research site on Devon Island and conducts experiments throughout the year.

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: How does paragraph 14 relate to paragraph 4?

A.Choice: Paragraph 14 explains the effect of the event in paragraph 4.

B.Choice: Paragraph 14 gives a solution to the problem introduced in paragraph 4.

C.Choice: Paragraph 14 provides further details that summarize the event in paragraph 4.

D.Choice: Paragraph 14 provides further details that contrast the information in paragraph 4.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which sentence from the story best shows how Seema feels about going to America without Raju?

A.Choice: “I stood near the acacia tree growing at the edge of an abandoned lot and watched Raju's back as the dust rising from his shoes covered my white blouse and my beige pinafore.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Raju was my cousin, and I wanted to tell him that everything would be fine — but how could I?” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “Why had Kaka and Kaki told Uma and Raju, and why had Pappa told me?” (paragraph 21)

D.Choice: “Raju and I went to school together and were in the same class.” (paragraph 22)

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: What does paragraph 23 of the story suggest about Seema?

A.Choice: She does not want to spoil her father's mood.

B.Choice: She does not have to convince her mother to stay.

C.Choice: She is upset that her father's laboratory job keeps him busy.

D.Choice: She is scared to be away from her mother.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: “School was over, and I would never wear this uniform again.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “I never could understand how Pappa could forget his lunch while working with tiny bugs that he could only see under a microscope.” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “When I went to bed, I wondered how I could leave the rest of my family and go to America.” (paragraph 22)

D.Choice: “The next morning I was tired and groggy.” (paragraph 24)

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which detail from the story best demonstrates the relationship among all the members of Seema's family?

A.Choice: Seema goes to the same school as her cousin.

B.Choice: Seema spends most of her time with her cousin.

C.Choice: The members of Seema's family visit each other.

D.Choice: The members of Seema's family live in the same house.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence best expresses a theme of the story?

A.Choice: Families often work together to accept change.

B.Choice: Change provides new opportunities.

C.Choice: Change can be difficult to accept.

D.Choice: It is impossible to avoid change.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Why do scientists want to create robots that imitate human facial expressions?

A.Choice: to encourage people to buy robots to do their tasks

B.Choice: to encourage people to pay more attention to robotic work

C.Choice: to help create a better connection between robots and people

D.Choice: to help establish a reason for robots and people to work together

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Which evidence best supports the idea that robots could be in every household by the year 2025?

A.Choice: Robots can perform daily tasks.

B.Choice: Robots can work in many places.

C.Choice: Robots can show human emotions.

D.Choice: Robots can replace human workers.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Which evidence best supports the idea that Nao will be a popular invention?

A.Choice: Nao is able to talk and walk.

B.Choice: Nao has a number of different uses.

C.Choice: Nao is the first robot to pick up toys.

D.Choice: Nao has been praised by robotic experts.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Based on the article, which statement best explains what Nexi, Nao, and RIBA have in common?

A.Choice: They interact and communicate with humans.

B.Choice: They have many possible military applications.

C.Choice: They can perform medical services that pose difficulties to people.

D.Choice: They are designed to imitate human emotions and facial expressions.

SubTopics: Use context (e.g., cause/effect relationships and comparisons in text) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Content: What does the expression “making a splash” (paragraph 10) mean?

A.Choice: getting soaked

B.Choice: swimming along

C.Choice: creating excitement

D.Choice: cleaning up

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which detail best shows that robots can perform tasks that are difficult for humans?

A.Choice: “They're in more places than you might know.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Some homes have robots that vacuum floors or mow the lawn.” (paragraph 1)

C.Choice: “You might be living or working with one of them one day!” (paragraph 2)

D.Choice: “It can also locate submerged ships or oil and gas pipelines.” (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: A robotic penguin was designed by engineers in Germany.

B.Choice: Because Nexi can raise its eyebrows, it can express feelings and emotions.

C.Choice: Nao is a two-foot-tall robot that can be programmed to perform several tasks.

D.Choice: Because some new robots act like humans in many ways, they will work well with people.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Presidential Pets,” what is the most likely reason that Barack Obama decided to get a new puppy when he was elected president? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Content: According to “[Excerpt from] Presidential Pets,” how have pets historically affected life at the White House? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).

Content: How does 'Cesca's father feel about his daughter? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: How do both 'Cesca and the American girl feel about the gondola? Use two details from the story to support your response.

Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: Why does Roy feel that he needs to keep his reading of the fairy-tale book a secret? Use two details from the story to support your response.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast stories in the same genre (e.g., mysteries and adventure stories) on their approaches to similar themes and topics.
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: In both “'Cesca's Reward” and “Roy's Secret,” the main characters learn lessons. What do 'Cesca and Roy learn from the adults in the stories? How do 'Cesca and Roy show that they have learned these lessons? Use details from both stories to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• explain what 'Cesca and Roy learn from the adults in the stories
• describe how 'Cesca and Roy show that they have learned these lessons
• use details from both stories to support your response
